OVERVIEW: The Decantel series consists of shallow, well drained soils that formed in material weathered from lava rocks and ash.  Decantel soils are on lava plains and benches and have slopes of 1 to 12 percent.  The mean annual precipitation is about 12 inches and the mean annual temperature is about 44 degrees F.

TAXONOMIC CLASS.content: TAXONOMIC CLASS: Clayey, smectitic, frigid, shallow Abruptic Argiduridic Durixerolls

TYPICAL PEDON.content:
TYPICAL PEDON:  Decantel loam, on a slope of 3 percent in sagebrush steppe at elevation of 4,500 feet.  (Colors are for dry soil unless otherwise noted.)
A1--0 to 5 inches; grayish brown (10YR 5/2) loam, very dark grayish brown (10YR 3/2) moist; weak thin platy structure parting to weak very fine granular; slightly hard, friable, slightly sticky and slightly plastic; many very fine roots; many very fine irregular pores; neutral (pH 6.6); clear wavy boundary.  (3 to 6 inches thick)
A2--5 to 8 inches; grayish brown (10YR 5/2) loam, very dark grayish brown (10YR 3/2) moist; weak coarse platy structure parting to weak very fine granular; soft, friable, slightly sticky and slightly plastic; many very fine roots; many very fine irregular pores; neutral (pH 6.6); clear wavy boundary.  (0 to 5 inches thick)
AB--8 to 13 inches; grayish brown (10YR 5/2) loam, dark brown (10YR 3/3) moist; moderate medium and fine subangular blocky structure; hard, friable, sticky and slightly plastic; common very fine roots; common very fine tubular pores; neutral (pH 7.0); abrupt wavy boundary.
Bt--13 to 17 inches; brown (10YR 5/3) clay, dark brown (10YR 3/3) moist; dark brown (10YR 4/3) crushed and moist; moderate medium and fine prismatic structure parting to moderate fine angular blocky; very hard, very firm, very sticky and very plastic; few very fine roots; many very fine tubular pores; few moderately thick clay films on ped faces; common thin clay films in pores; many uncoated mineral grains on top and upper edge of prisms; neutral (pH 7.0); abrupt wavy boundary.  (3 to 10 inches thick)
2Bqm--17 to 22 inches; very pale brown (10YR 7/4) very cobbly duripan, dark brown (10YR 4/3) moist; platy; indurated; opal laminar cap 1 to 3 millimeters thick at top of pan, thick opal coatings on plates.

TYPE LOCATION.content: TYPE LOCATION:  Crook County, Oregon; NE1/4 SE1/4 SW1/4 section 6, T. 20 S., R. 22 E.

RANGE IN CHARACTERISTICS.content:
RANGE IN CHARACTERISTICS:  Soils are moist in winter and spring.  They are warmer than 41 degrees F.
f.om April 1 to November 1, and they are dry within this period after July 1.  The mean annual soil temperature ranges from 44 to 47 degrees F.  Depth to the duripan ranges from 13 to 20 inches.  Depth to bedrock is more than 60 inches.  The solum is neutral in the upper part and neutral through moderately alkaline in the lower part.  The depth to the Bt horizon is 10 to 17 inches.
The A horizon has value of 2 or 3 moist.  The A horizon has 0 to 15 percent gravel.
The Bt horizon has value of 5 or 6 dry and 3 or 4 moist, and chroma of 3 or 4 dry and moist.  This horizon is 40 to 55 percent clay and 0 to 35 percent gravel.  The Bt has prismatic or columnar structure.  A thin E horizon and BA horizon is present in some pedons.  The duripan is calcareous in some pedons.

COMPETING SERIES.content: COMPETING SERIES:  These are the Donna, Gibbs, and Lamonta series in other families.  Donna soils are more than 60 percent clay and have a duripan at depths of 20 to 26 inches.  Gibbs soils are mesic and deeper than 20 inches over the duripan.  Lamonta soils are mesic, 20 to 30 inches deep over duripan and formed in material of sedimentary origin.

GEOGRAPHIC SETTING.content: GEOGRAPHIC SETTING:  Decantel soils are on lava plains and benches at elevations of 4,300 to 4,600 feet.  Slopes range from 1 to 12 percent.  The soils formed in material weathered from lava rocks and pumiceous ash.  The climate is characterized by cold moist winters and warm dry summers.  Mean annual precipitation is 11 to 13 inches.  The mean annual temperature is 43 to 45 degrees F., mean January temperature is 27 to 29 degrees F., and mean July temperature is 59 to 61 degrees F.  The frost-free period is 50 to 90 days.

GEOGRAPHICALLY ASSOCIATED SOILS.content: GEOGRAPHICALLY ASSOCIATED SOILS:  These are the Beden (T), Blayden (T), Mascamp, Simatron and Varco (T) soils.  Beden and Blayden soils are loamy.  Mascamp soils are loamy-skeletal and lack a duripan.  Simatron soils are deep and lack a duripan.  Varco soils have an ochric epipedon.

DRAINAGE AND PERMEABILITY.content: DRAINAGE AND PERMEABILITY:  Well drained, rapid runoff, slow permeability.

USE AND VEGETATION.content: USE AND VEGETATION:  Range and wildlife habitat.  Native vegetation mainly is Idaho fescue, bluebunch wheatgrass, Sandberg bluegrass, big sagebrush, and western juniper.

DISTRIBUTION AND EXTENT.content: DISTRIBUTION AND EXTENT:  Central Oregon east of the Cascade Mountains.  The series is of minor extent.

REGIONAL OFFICE.section: MLRA SOIL SURVEY REGIONAL OFFICE (MO) RESPONSIBLE
REGIONAL OFFICE.content: MLRA SOIL SURVEY REGIONAL OFFICE (MO) RESPONSIBLE: Portland, Oregon

ORIGIN.content:
SERIES PROPOSED:  Prineville District Area, BLM, Crook County, Oregon, 1980.  The name is coined.
NSTH 17, RECLASSIFICATION ONLY, 3/95
